Colmar, France: A hidden gem in the Alsace region

Colmar is a charming city located in the Alsace region of France, near the border with Germany. It is known for its well-preserved medieval old town, its picturesque canals, and its colorful half-timbered houses. Colmar is also a major center for Alsatian wine production, and there are many vineyards and wineries to visit in the surrounding area.

Things to do in Colmar

Explore the old town: The old town of Colmar is a maze of narrow cobblestone streets and alleyways, lined with half-timbered houses and shops. Be sure to visit the Place Rapp, a lively square surrounded by cafes and restaurants, and the Collegiate Church of Saint Martin, a beautiful Gothic church built in the 13th century.

Take a boat tour: One of the best ways to see Colmar is on a boat tour. There are several different companies that offer tours, which typically last around an hour. You’ll cruise along the canals and see the city from a different perspective.

Visit the Unterlinden Museum: The Unterlinden Museum is one of the most important museums in Alsace. It is home to the Isenheim Altarpiece, a masterpiece of medieval art. The museum also has a collection of paintings, sculptures, and other artifacts from the region.

Go wine tasting: Colmar is located in the heart of the Alsatian Wine Route, so there are many opportunities to go wine tasting. You can visit vineyards and wineries on your own, or join a guided tour. There are also many wine bars and restaurants in Colmar where you can sample different Alsatian wines.

Hidden gems in Colmar

The Pfifferhus: The Pfifferhus is a beautiful half-timbered house built in the 16th century. It is located in the heart of the old town, and it is one of the most photographed buildings in Colmar.

The Saint-Pierre Canal: The Saint-Pierre Canal is a small canal that runs through the old town. It is lined with willow trees and flowers, and it is a popular spot for locals and tourists alike to take a walk or have a picnic.

The Old Covered Market: The Old Covered Market is a historic market hall that was built in the 19th century. It is now home to a variety of shops and restaurants, and it is a great place to find local produce and souvenirs.

The Colmar Miniature Railway: The Colmar Miniature Railway is a fun activity for the whole family. It is a miniature railway that runs through a park, and it features models of Alsatian villages and countryside.

When to visit Colmar

Colmar is a beautiful city to visit at any time of year. However, the best time to visit depends on your interests. If you want to enjoy the warm weather and the outdoor activities, then spring and summer are the best times to visit. If you want to experience the city’s Christmas markets, then winter is the best time to visit.

How to get to Colmar

Colmar is located in the Alsace region of France, near the border with Germany. The nearest major airport is Basel Mulhouse Freiburg Airport, which is located about 45 kilometers from Colmar. There are also several train stations in Colmar, which connect the city to major cities in France and Germany.

Getting around Colmar

Colmar is a relatively small city, and it is easy to get around on foot or by bicycle. There is also a public bus system that serves the city.

Where to stay in Colmar

There are a variety of hotels and guesthouses to choose from in Colmar. If you are looking for a central location, then the old town is a good place to stay. If you are looking for a more budget-friendly option, then there are several hotels and guesthouses located outside of the old town.

Where to eat in Colmar

Colmar has a variety of restaurants to choose from, serving both traditional Alsatian cuisine and international fare. Be sure to try some of the local specialties, such as tarte flambée (a thin pizza-like dish topped with crème fraîche, onions, and bacon) or choucroute (sauerkraut with sausage and other meats).

Tips for visiting Colmar

Book your accommodation in advance, especially if you are visiting during peak season.

Wear comfortable shoes, as you will be doing a lot of walking.

Be prepared for all types of weather, as the weather in Colmar can change quickly.

Learn a few basic French phrases, as this will help you to communicate with locals.

Be sure to try some of the local specialties, such as tarte flambée and choucroute.
